moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5
comment:
? - Here Steinitz shows poor judgment, since he
will be left with a doubled, isolated "b" pawn and a weak "d" pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2
comment: Now Black threatens to come out a pawn ahead by ...Ra6.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2 15. Bb6 Be7 16. c3 Kf7 17. Kc2 Rha8 18. Kb3 R2a4 19. f3 R8a6 20. Bd4 g6 21. Rd3 Ke8 22. Rhd1 e5
comment:
Obviously a very bad move, but a difficult one to avoid in view of Black's
pawns position. The text not only permanently weakens the "d" pawn, but allows
White to attack the "b" pawn as well.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2 15. Bb6 Be7 16. c3 Kf7 17. Kc2 Rha8 18. Kb3 R2a4 19. f3 R8a6 20. Bd4 g6 21. Rd3 Ke8 22. Rhd1 e5 23. Be3 Kd7
comment:
Enables White to post his
Bishop on the diagonal a3-f8. But Black must protect the "b" pawn, for White
already threatens Rd3-d5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2 15. Bb6 Be7 16. c3 Kf7 17. Kc2 Rha8 18. Kb3 R2a4 19. f3 R8a6 20. Bd4 g6 21. Rd3 Ke8 22. Rhd1 e5 23. Be3 Kd7 24. Bc5

1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2 15. Bb6 Be7 16. c3 Kf7 17. Kc2 Rha8 18. Kb3 R2a4 19. f3 R8a6 20. Bd4 g6 21. Rd3 Ke8 22. Rhd1 e5 23. Be3 Kd7 24. Bc5 Ra1 25. R1d2 Ke6 26. Ba3 g5 27. Rd5 Rb6 28. Kb4 g4
comment:
In contrast to his weak and colorless play in the early
part of the game, Steinitz plays now with great energy. Lasker's play however
is also on a high level. The object of the text is of course to weaken White's
king side pawns.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Nc3 a6 5. Bc4 Be6 6. Bxe6 fxe6 7. d4 exd4 8. Nxd4 Nxd4 9. Qxd4 Ne7 10. Bg5 Nc6 11. Bxd8 Nxd4 12. O-O-O Nb5 13. Nxb5 axb5 14. Bxc7 Rxa2 15. Bb6 Be7 16. c3 Kf7 17. Kc2 Rha8 18. Kb3 R2a4 19. f3 R8a6 20. Bd4 g6 21. Rd3 Ke8 22. Rhd1 e5 23. Be3 Kd7 24. Bc5 Ra1 25. R1d2 Ke6 26. Ba3 g5 27. Rd5 Rb6 28. Kb4 g4 29. Ka5
comment: This move has the merit of semplicity.

Rd1 Rxd1 32. Rxd1 gxf3 33. gxf3 Ra8 34. Kb6 Rg8 35. Kxb7 Rg2 36. h4 Rh2 37. Kc6 Bxh4 38. Rxd6+ Kf7 39. Kd5 Bf6 40. Rd7+ Kg6 41. Ke6 h4 42. Rd1 h3 43. Rg1+ Rg2 44. Rxg2+ hxg2 45. comment:
Resign. La
sker's best game in this match. (Comentarios de R. Fine y F. Reinfeld en "La
carrera de ajedrez del Dr. Lasker")
